title: Balancer - Removal

body.body: Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
An unstable motorcycle may fall, causing injury to the operator or damage to the motorcycle.
With the crankcase halves separated, lift out the balancer shaft complete with the shaft bearings/circlips.
As the shaft is released from the crankcase, the backlash eliminator gear will spring out of alignment with the crankshaft.
To remove the left hand bearing, slide the bearing, circlip and bearing sleeve from the balancer shaft. Note the orientation of the bearing prior to removal.

To remove the right hand bearing, remove the circlip and washer, and, using a press and press bars remove the bearing race from the shaft, ensuring the inner bearing race is supported. Note the orientation of the bearing prior to removal. DO NOT remove the drive gear from the shaft.

When using a press, always wear overalls, eye, face and hand protection. Objects such as bearings frequently break-up under load and the debris caused during break-up may cause damage and injury to unprotected parts of the body.
Never wear loose clothing, which could become trapped in the press and cause crushing injury to the hand, arms or other parts of the anatomy.

Do not remove the drive gear from the balancer shaft. The drive gear is aligned to the shaft. If the balancer and drive gear are not correctly aligned, severe engine vibration will occur leading to damage to components.
To strip the backlash eliminator from the drive gear, release the circlip and remove the wave-washer, backlash gear and spring.
